results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 39]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This film shows the Gadsdens gathering at Surfers Paradise in Queensland, for Easter in 1987. We see swimming and general beach activity, surfing and paddling in the waves. There is an Easter egg hunt in the holiday house yard and we also see the a barbeque on a 1970s three-legged hotplate and beers being drunk from ‘stubby holders’.

This film was originally made using Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:07:03:00 cooking on a 1970s three-legged barbeque

This film shows sailing activities at the Davey’s Bay Yacht Club as well as yacht racing off the Mornington Peninsula, Victoria.

This film was originally made using Super 8mm film.

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 34]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This film shows the Gadsdens at Thredbo and Perisher, ski resorts in the Snowy Mountains of New South Wales. They and their friends are having fun in very snowy conditions on the slopes, coming and going from their accommodation, the ski lifts, throwing snowballs and wearing examples of circa 1969 skiing outfits. Indoor scenes give an indication of everyday life on these holidays, such as using a fondue set at the dinner table, joking around for the camera whilst preparing for bed and some holiday knitting. There are views of the majestic mountain scenery and of the townships.

This film was originally made using Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:03:15:00 snow vehicle with passengers
00:05:30:00 views of the accommodation indicate the depth of the snow and the general snowy conditions
00:11:56:00 one of the Gadsden daughters enjoys a quiet moment of knitting
00:12:30:00 an example of 1970s style fondue sharing at the table
00:13:08:00 Jess Gadsden in the kitchen.

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 33]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This film contains footage of the National Titles skiing competition at Thredbo in NSW. The end of the reel shows the end of games gathering where the skiiers (still with skis strapped on) are in fancy dress for the presentation of awards and drinking beers as the sun goes down.

This film was originally made using Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:23:23:00 skiiers in fancy dress for awards

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 29]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This film captures the building of a dam at ‘Mooltunya’, the Gadsden family farm in country Victoria. It begins with spectacular hailstones but primarily captures the construction of a dam.

This film was originally made using Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:22:00 a handful of large hailstones.
00:02:59:00 earthworks for dam construction

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 28]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This film shows a visit to ‘Mooltunya’, which was Ronald and Jess Gadsden’s farm in regional Victoria. Members of the Gadsden family and friends circle participate in the various activities at the farm, including helping with farm work.

Toward the end of the film there are scenes of yachts sailing around a bay which is likely to be Port Phillip Bay.

This film was originally made using Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:43:00 the ‘Mooltunya’ farmgate
00:03:23:00 younger family members trying out horses
00:05:00:00 painting the farm house roof
00:06:11:00 spray painting the house atop a ladder across the roof
00:08:04:00 a new ‘David Brown 880’ tractor and slasher being used for slashing in the paddock
00:11:10:00 a younger Gadsden using the tractor and slasher at speed
00:18:42:00 installing a windmill by being at the very top
00:20:57:00 cows seeking shade under a tree
00:21:03:00 scene changes for sailing
00:23:08:00 hay making at the farm

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 21]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This reel contains scenes from the family farm, ‘Mooltunya’ in Victoria where we see the flooded creek as well as hay baling and carting hay. The hay-making is a good example of the square smaller bales produced at the time (before large spun round bales) and the manual labour involved in collecting and stacking the bales.

This film was originally made using Super 8mm film.

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 3]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This reel opens with the title ‘Surfers Paradise May 1975’ written in the sand between waves. The subtitle ‘Passing Parade’ shows the filmmakers intention: life on the beach on the Gold Coast at the time. The reel begins with early morning scenes of both the beach and the duplex holiday house situated right on the sand. We see lots of surfing – board surfing, body surfing and a longboard with paddles. We also see a large jellyfish in the sand, frisbee playing, strolling along the sand in 1970s fashion flares, Gadsdens running in a group along the beach, family members fishing, a commercial fishing boat in the waves, knitting on a towel on sand, sitting on the house balcony with drinks, a barbeque on the rooftop and views along the coastline.

This film was originally made using Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:01:56:00 ice cream cart on the beach
00:13:14:00 the filmmaker himself enjoying a XXXX beer while smiling for the camera
00:13:53:00 mid-rise apartment blocks along the coast more sparsely spaced than now

results.title: [Douglas Wilson Home Movies: Reel 5]
results.brief_description:
Douglas Wilson (1919–1980) was an amateur filmmaker whose films are a snapshot of Australia in the 1950s to 1960s. Douglas’s home movies captured aspects of life in Australia’s major cities as well as in regional areas, often with a focus on public areas, transport or infrastructure projects. A collection of his films has been donated to ACMI by a member of Douglas’s family.

The first part of this film briefly shows an outdoor art show before moving on to water ski jumping on the Yarra River – both are part of the ‘Moomba’ celebrations. The second part shows a road trip from Glenroy to Macedon ending at ‘Cameron Lodge’, Macedon all in Victoria.

Good views of the water ski jumping and the crowds watching from the banks. The road trip shows excellent views of small towns such as Keilor and Diggers Rest, vehicles passing on country roads and roadside scenes including telegraph poles.

Extensive views of the gardens of Cameron Lodge in Macedon including the rotunda, lake, stepping stones and family scenes in the garden.

Originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:00:00 outdoor art show
00:00:44:00 Yarra River
00:01:00:00 the ‘Moomba’ festival on the riverbank
00:01:14:00 water skiing
00:02:00:00 water skiing over a jump
00:02:30:00 crowd watching from riverbank
00:03:40:00 title card ‘Glenroy to Macedon 4-3-61’
00:03:47:00 footage of car trip filmed from moving car showing country roads
00:04:38:00 car parked next to Keilor road sign. Good views of cars on road including VW beetle and Holdens, views of telegraph poles
00:05:05:00 road bridge with curved arch
00:05:10:00 ‘Keilor Hotel’ and parked cars, street scenes
00:05:20:00 Diggers Rest town scenes
00:05:40:00 countryside from moving car
00:06:35:00 Jacksons Creek bridge
00:07:28:00 small town with parked Holdens and BP service station
00:07:46:00 title card ‘Cameron Lodge Macedon 4-3-61’
00:07:52:00 views of Cameron Lodge and man walking in gardens
00:08:24:00 views of garden rotunda
00:08:37:00 two women and baby in lodge garden
00:08:40:00 man photographing garden
00:08:47:00 man in rotunda surrounded by lake, crossing stepping stones
00:09:21:00 group walk through lush vegetation including tree ferns
00:09:46:00 walking through lodge garden
00:10:03:00 children playing in rotunda and on stepping stones
00:10:46:00 group of children and adults on lakeside steps
00:11:10:00 title card ‘The End’
